metadata.title: Pursuing two-dimensional nanomaterials for flexible lithium-ion batteries

sections.text:
ARTICLE IN PRESS+ModelNANTOD-495; No. of Pages 16 Nano Today (2016) xxx, xxx—xxx
Available online at www.sciencedirect.com
ScienceDirect
j our na l ho me pag e: www.elsev ier .com/ locate /nanotoday
REVIEW
Pursuing two-dimensional nanomaterials for flexible lithium-ion batteries
Bin Liua,b, Ji-Guang Zhanga,∗, Guozhen Shenb,∗
a Energy and Environment Directorate, Pacific Northwest National Laboratory, Richland, WA 99354, United States b State Key Laboratory for Superlattices and Microstructures, Institute of Semiconductors, Chinese Academy of Sciences, Beijing 100083, PR China
Received 31 January 2016; accepted 10 February 2016
KEYWORDS Two-dimensional; Flexible batteries; Nanomaterials; Potential application
Summary Stretchable/flexible electronics provide a foundation for various emerging applications that beyond the scope of conventional wafer/circuit board technologies due to their unique features that can satisfy a broad range of applications such as wearable devices. Stretchable electronic and optoelectronics devices require the bendable/wearable rechargeable Li-ion batteries, thus these devices can operate without limitation of external powers. Various two-dimensional (2D) nanomaterials are of great interest in flexible energy storage devices, especially Li-ion batteries. This is because 2D materials exhibit much more exposed surface area supplying abundant Li-insertion channels and shortened paths for fast lithium ion diffusion. Here, we will review the recent developments on the flexible Li-ion batteries based on two dimensional nanomaterials. These researches demonstrated advancements in flexible electronics by incorporating various 2D nanomaterials into bendable batteries to achieve high electrochemical performance, excellent mechanical flexibility as well as electrical stability under stretching/bending conditions. © 2016 Elsevier Ltd. All rights reserved.
t Introduction
Please cite this article in press as: B. Liu, et al., Nano Today (2
Increasing demands for high-efficiency, environmentally friendly and low-cost energy sources are associated with

Among various energy storage ystems, rechargeable lithium-ion batteries are one of the ost promising power sources to alleviate energy crisis 10—15]. Although significant progresses have been made n Li-ion batteries (LIBs) in the last a few decades, most
016), http://dx.doi.org/10.1016/j.nantod.2016.02.003
f these batteries are still short of features of such as exibility, bendability, wear-ability, which forms a barrier or the development of next-generation flexible optoelecronic products [16—24]. The increasing interest in flexible

nd stretchable electronics has promoted the rapid develpment of flexible batteries. Here, all these components including cathode, anode, electrolyte, separator, and packng material) in a flexible battery need to be flexible and endable. The paramount goal of on-going research on flexble batteries is to smoothly maintain the expected battery tability under various bending states. Moreover, different urving and stretching level of flexible rechargeable batteres would be designed and fabricated, depending on their arious application fields, while the traditional batteries are igid with certain shapes. Thus, significant efforts are being ade around world to fabricate highly flexible rechargeable atteries [25—35].
To overcome the tremendous challenge of fabrication f highly stable flexible Li-ion batteries, utilizing nanotructure materials to prepare electrodes is one of the ost promising strategies. It is well-known that nanomaerials can be classified in four categories: zero dimensional 0D), one dimensional (1D), two dimensional (2D), and three imensional (3D). Here, 0D structures (nano/microsphere) old the minimum surface area, and exhibit excellent hermal stability. 1D structures (nanotubes/nanowires) fabicated by oriented growth have a potential application or micro-devices. 2D structures (nanosheets) often have arge exposed surfaces, and specific facets. In general, D structures could be obtained by introducing structure irecting agents (SDAs) or assembled by 0D, 1D, and 2D tructures [36]. In particular, comparing to 0D, and 1D anomaterials, 2D nanomaterials exhibit many unique feaures, such as small weight, large surface area, sensible istribution, more active sites with effective surface. Thereore, it would be highly desirable to use 2D nanomaterials n the design and preparation of flexible energy storage evices.
In this review, we will focus on advances on typical twoimensional (2D) functional materials for flexible/bendable ithium-ion batteries, such as flexible 2D graphene paper, arious graphene-based composite cathodes and anodes, D inorganic nanosheets, etc., as shown in Fig. 1. How o better understand the selection, design, and optimizaion of these aforementioned bendable and free-standing lectrodes should be a key sweet spot for next-generation exible LIBs chemistries. It is expected that this overview
Please cite this article in press as: B. Liu, et al., Nano Today (2
ill not only summarize the highlighted developments of 2D anomaterials-based flexible energy storage field but also hine light on the directions for further development of 2D unctional nanomaterials for various applications.

ecently, more and more interests were focused on portable nd bendable electronic units such as roll-up displays, earable devices, and implanted medical devices [37,38]. owever, the design and fabrication of bendable batter-
es is facing a significant challenge: how to find reliable exible materials with robust strength, good conductivty, and excellent electrical stability under bending. Among wo-dimensional materials, graphene is an atom-thick twoimensional carbon sheet. The carbon—carbon bond is the trongest single bond in nature, resulting in graphene with igh Young’s modulus and tensile strength [39]. Therefore, raphene as active material was also smoothly introduced nto high performance flexible energy storage devices due to heir potential superiority in terms of mechanical flexibility nd charge-carrier mobility [40].
lexible two-dimensional graphene paper
raphene paper has dual functions and can act both as a onducting agent and a current collector. Clearly, based on raphene’s features, the graphene paper itself holds some nique properties, making it a key factor for development f flexible LIBs [41—44]. Fabrication of graphene papers as been reported previously [41,43—45]. Briefly, it is well nown that graphite oxide can be synthesized from graphite owder by oxidation using a typical Hummers method [46]. hen, graphene paper was usually fabricated by filtraion of graphene dispersions [41,43—45,47]. Koratkar et al. ntroduced photothermal reduction of graphene oxide to btain graphene paper anodes; the corresponding proceures and characterizations are shown in Fig. 2a—d [44]. learly, a free-standing graphene paper exhibits good bendble features (Fig. 2c) so it is a good candidate to be used n flexible-batteries. In Fig. 2e, these flexible graphene aper electrodes showed excellent cycling stability over 000 discharge/charge times and high rate capability (20 C, 0 C, 100 C, and 150 C). Clearly, extensive developments of raphene papers will trigger more research on flexible optolectronics in the near future. Liu et al. fabricated the
016), http://dx.doi.org/10.1016/j.nantod.2016.02.003
exible graphene paper made from the graphene aerogel re-synthesized by freeze-drying a GO aqueous dispersion nd subsequent thermal reduction [48]. The free-standing raphene paper shows excellent flexibility as shown in
on 2D graphene paper, 2D graphene/active cathode-material, sheets/carbon composites.

raphene/MnO2 nanotube hybrid film [53], have been eveloped. Most functional materials were deposited onto re-obtained graphene paper via hydrothermal, filtration, mmersion followed by thermal decomposition methods 50—54]. For example, Hu et al. reported an ex situ method o prepare a flexible graphene/TiO2 nanoparticles hybrid aper electrode [49]. Because of the highly conductive raphene network, the flexible composite paper electrode eaches a capacity of 122 mAh g−1 at 2 A g−1 after 100 cycles. urface structure is considered as a key factor to deterine the rate of the Li+ ion de-intercalation/intercalation rocess. Yang et al. fabricated Co3O4 fibers using elecrospinning technique, then got graphene/Co3O4 fibers omposite papers by depositing graphene nanosheets on o3O4 active materials via electrostatic interaction, indicatng a large reversible capacity (840 mAh g−1 after 40 cycles), nd improved cycling stability [51]. Liang et al. prepared exible free-standing graphene/SnO2 nanocomposite papers y a facile filtration route together with a thermal reduction 52]. To utilize unique respective advantages of SnO2 and raphene, the SnO2 nanoparticles are embedded into layers f 2D graphene sheets, two layers including SnO2 nanopartiles and graphene sheets are distributed uniformly, as shown n different magnification FESEM cross-section and topiew images (Fig. 4a—e). An as-synthesized free-standing nO2/graphene film can be bent by a tweezer, thus indicatng its excellent flexibility (Fig. 4f). Although graphene/SnO2 omposite electrodes exhibited a low capacity during the rst few cycles due to poor electrolyte wetting of the dense raphene/SnO2 paper, their corresponding discharge capacty still reach 428 mAh g−1 after 50 cycles (about 83.4% etention those at 25th cycle), as illustrated in Fig. 4g. In ontrary, bare SnO2 electrodes delivered poor cycling staility. Fig. 4h shows that the graphene/SnO2 electrode in he high-medium frequency region exhibits a much smaller harge transfer resistance than that of the SnO2 electrode as revealed by a much smaller diameter of the semicircle n the impedance spectra of the graphene/SnO2 electrode). uang et al. loaded the transition-metal oxides (Fe3O4, o3O4, and NiO) into the nanoporous graphene papers via
general wet-immersion route to form free-standing flexile composite papers. These flexible composite electrodes xhibited enhanced electrochemical performance [54].
Beside above binary inorganic materials, because silion has very high theoretical capacity (4200 mAh g−1), it has een combined with graphene with unique features to synhesize bendable free-standing hybrid anodes for flexible i-ion batteries [55—57]. For example, Wang et al. proosed fabrication of flexible and paper-like graphene-silicon omposites by a one-step in situ filtration method [58]. he flexible graphene-Si composite electrodes showed much igher discharge capacity over 100 cycles (708 mAh g−1) han that of the graphene electrodes (304 mAh g−1). Here, D graphene can serve as a flexible mechanical and effiient electrically conducting support. In addition to flexible wo-component (graphene-Si) electrode, flexible binderree SiNW@G@RGO hybrid materials were also designed 56]. Firstly, SiNW@G nanocables were grown via chemical
016), http://dx.doi.org/10.1016/j.nantod.2016.02.003
apor deposition (CVD) approach. Then, SiNW@G nanocales were dispersed in GO solution. The homogeneous ixture was vacuum filtered, peeled from the filter memrane. Finally, flexible SiNW@G@RGO composite anodes

lexible two-dimensional graphene composite athodes
n addition to composite anodes, various cathode materials ere also incorporated into 2D graphene films by using catlyst assisted self-assembly, co-precipitation, pulsed laser eposition (PLD), microwave hydrothermal, and phototheral reduction methods [59,60,62—64]. These composite athodes include graphene/LiFePO4 nanoparticles [59—61], raphene/V2O5 films [62], graphene/MoO3 nanobelts [63], nd graphene/FeF3 nanoparticles [64]. Li et al. proposed
new design of flexible batteries based on Li4Ti5O12 LTO)/graphene form (GF) and LiFePO4 (LFP)/GF electrodes y hydrothermal deposition of active materials on GF folowed by heating in an argon atmosphere [61]. Fig. 6a shows he TEM images of LTO nanosheets/graphene composites. TO nanosheets are several hundred nanometers in width nd a few nanometers in thickness (Fig. 6b). Further, a TO/GF electrode was combined with a LFP/GF to form a exible full Li-ion battery (Fig. 6c). This flexible battery can
Please cite this article in press as: B. Liu, et al., Nano Today (2
moothly drive a red LED even under bending condition, as hown in Fig. 6d. From Fig. 6e and f, it can be seen that the ischarge/charge curves and cyclic stability of flexible batery are barely affected by external bendable stress, thus

emonstrating its good flexible electrical stability. Morever, Gwon et al. reported a flexible L-ion battery composed f bendable graphene paper and V2O5/graphene paper as node and cathode, respectively, as illustrated in Fig. 7a—c 62]. Here, the graphene paper made via a vacuum filtration nd V2O5 films can be grown onto graphene paper by using
pulsed laser deposition (PLD) in a vacuum chamber. The exible battery can be discharged and charged when rolled p, revealing its potential feasibility in flexible electronics Fig. 7b). The V2O5/graphene paper electrode showed etter performance in terms of capacity, rate capability as ell as cycling life, compared to non-flexible traditional 2O5/Al foil electrode (Fig. 7d and e). In addition, Noeochim et al. introduced highly flexible binder-free MoO3 anobelt/graphene film electrode into fabrication of bendble Li-ion batteries via a two-step micro-wave hydrotheral method [63]. The as-prepared flexible MoO3/graphene ybrid electrodes showed excellent rate capability, nhanced capacity, and superior cyclic stability, compared o the sole MoO3 electrodes. The progresses in flexible 2D raphene-based composite cathodes can be combined with raphene-based composite anodes mentioned above.

016), http://dx.doi.org/10.1016/j.nantod.2016.02.003
atteries were reported. For example, Li et al. proposed n anisotropic flexible electrode fabricated by controlling he growth of TiO2 nanosheets parallel to the surface of he graphene paper, which results in the Li+ ion insertion

The cycling performance at 10 C between the iO2 nanosheets/graphene and TiO2 spheres/graphene elecrodes, TiO2 nanosheets/graphene anodes delivered around 50 mAh g−1 over 100 cyclic times, which exhibits supeior cyclic stability than TiO2 spheres/graphene composites Fig. 8e). Firstly, fabrication of the ACF y electrospinning and thermal activation in CO2 was conucted. Then, TiO2 (B) nanosheets were deposited onto arbon fabric film using hydrolysis approach followed by hermal annealing. The photograph of an as-prepared elecrode shows its free-standing, flexible properties (Fig. 9a). hese bendable electrodes can be easily punched into disc lectrodes to fit for the coin-cell size, as shown in Fig. 9b. learly, numerous fibers from non-woven ACF were coated ith 2D uniform TiO2 nanosheets, thus facilitating enhanceent in electrical contact between TiO2 active materials
nd carbon substrate (Fig. 9c—e). The charge/discharge proles of TiO2 (B)/ACF electrodes indicate the large capacity
oss in the first cycle due to the interfacial reaction between iO2 (B) and the LiPF6-based electrolyte, which should be ommon phenomenon for most lithium-intercalation hosts Fig. 9f). After 1000 cycles, the specific capacity of TiO2 B)/ACF electrodes still be close to 200 mAh g−1 (85% capac-

ty retention). Corresponding Coulombic efficiency (CE) can aintain around 100% as well, except for initial several ycles (Fig. 9g). From this plot, it can be also seen that he contribution of bare ACF to total capacity is negligible.

ompared to anatase TiO2 nanoparticles-based electrodes, iO2 (B) nnaosheets/ACF electrodes demonstrate enhanced ate-capability, as well as even hold stable cycling at 20 C or 2000 cycles (Fig. 9h and i, respectively). In this study, his type of flexible electrodes would hold a great potential or the development of flexible energy storage units with igh power and energy densities.
Moreover, Liu et al. proposed a free-standing flexible uO nanosheets (NSs)/r-GO composites fabricated by a acuum filtration method and hydrothermal reduction rocess, as illustrated in Fig. 10a [72]. CuO NSs can be niformly incorporated between r-GO layers, which seem ike layer-by-layer sandwiched architecture (Fig. 10b and ). Within, r-GO layers can act as mechanical supporting nd current collector. Fig. 10c inset demonstrates the hoto of as-obtained highly flexible CuO NSs/r-GO comosite electrode. Corresponding cyclic performance of CuO Ss/r-GO, bare CuO NSs, bare r-GO electrodes at a current ensity of 67 mA g−1 (Fig. 10d). These CuO NSs/r-GO flexible lectrode can deliver the highest retaining discharge apacity (736.8 mAh g−1), which is much higher than that f CuO NSs-based electrodes. In addition, the discharge apacity of bare r-GO electrode is close to 60 mAh g−1 after 0 cycles, thus revealing that the total discharge capacity f CuO NSs/r-GO electrode should be mainly attributed to ontribution of CuO NSs.

n addition to the 2D oxide-based nanomaterials, fabrication f many sulfide-based 2D materials applied for rechargeble Li-ion batteries also attracted significant attentions.

t t ( M n e t f A e 9 Here, MoS2 has been considered as a potential candidate for electrode materials in Li-ion batteries due to its layered structure and high theoretical capacity. Thus, many interesting MoS2 nanosheets-based electrodes were synthesized using glucose-assisted hydrothermal method [73], solvothermal reaction at a low temperature [74], templateassisted strategy [75], hydrothermal process followed by annealing [76], coprecipitation combined with solvothermal route [77]. Furthermore, SnS2 nanosheets/MWCNTs coaxial nanocables were prepared via a modified layer-by-layer assembly approach [78].

In the recent literature, Balogun et al. proposed a vanaium nitride supported SnS2 nanosheets flexible electrodes or lithium-ion batteries [80]. Briefly, a highly flexible caron cloth (CC) film was firstly coated vanadium nitride VN) nanowires through hydrothermal and annealing proesses. Then, as-obtained CC-VN composite was immersed nto a solution of SnCl4 and L-cysteine at 180 ◦C for 6 h to ake SnS2 nanosheets coated onto the CC-VN surface. The otal two-step growth process can be found in Fig. 12a. he corresponding SEM and optical images of bare CC, CCN, and CC-VN/SnS2 are also provided in Fig. 12b and its nset, Fig. 12c and its inset, and Fig. 12d and its inset, espectively. Considering well-known woven carbon cloth ubstrate with excellent flexibility, carbon cloth coated N/SnS2 still can hold bendable/stretchable features for otential application in flexible Li-ion batteries. Clearly, C-VN/SnS2 nanosheets electrodes indicate excellent cyclic tability (up to 100 cycles), as shown in Fig. 12e. After 00 cycles, the discharge capacity of CC-VN/SnS2, CC-VN,
Please cite this article in press as: B. Liu, et al., Nano Today (2
nd CC-SnS2 electrodes are 791 mAh g−1, 322 mAh g−1, and 70 mAh g−1, respectively. Moreover, the CC-VN@SnS2 elecrodes show superior rate capability over the CC-VN, and C-SnS2 electrodes (Fig. 12f).

lexible two-dimensional multiple-compound anosheets composites
ecent progresses in multiple-compound nanosheets as elecrodes for lithium ion batteries, such as Li4Ti5O12 nanosheets 81,82], Li2FeSiO4 ultrathin nanosheets [83], and LiFePO4 anosheets [84], have already been disclosed. The multipleompound containing two or more types of metal ions deliver nhanced electrochemical performance due to their syneretic effects upon charge—discharge process [85,86]. Furher, with the rapid development of traditional non-flexible i-ion battery based multiple-compound nanosheets, some ultiple-compound nanosheets-based flexible electrodes ere also successfully achieved. For example, Xiong et al. esigned all-nanosheet-based Li-ion full battery using nMn2O4-graphene hybrid nanosheet and LiFePO4 nanosheet s anode and cathode [87], respectively, on basis of previous ynthesized methods [88,89]. ZnMn2O4 nanocrystals were ell dispersed on the surface of 2D graphene nanosheets to orm ZnMn2O4-graphene composite nanosheets, as shown in ig. 13a. The as-synthesized LiFePO4 nanosheets with thickess of 30—60 nm have uniform morphology (Fig. 13b). Furher, Fig. 13c indicates the galvanostatic discharge/charge easurements, which reveals that the 2D ZnMn2O4raphene composite electrodes delivered much larger pecific capacity, enhanced rate capability and superior yclic stability, compared to those of traditional graphite
016), http://dx.doi.org/10.1016/j.nantod.2016.02.003
lectrodes. Moreover, authors moved the LiFePO4 nanosheet athodes into the half-cells to measure rate capability, as isclosed in Fig. 13d. Compared to commercial LiFePO4, 2D iFePO4 nanosheets showed better rate performance due to

the LiFePO4 nanosheets with high oriented {0 1 0} surface could supply increased active surface area and shortened Li+ diffusion pathways [90,91]. Based on these half-cells, the 2D ZnMn2O4-graphene composite anode and 2D LiFePO4 nanosheets cathode were transferred into flexible/bendable full Li-ion batteries. This flexible battery exhibited excellent electrochemical stability without structural failure and capacity/CE loss under various mechanical bending states (Fig. 13e—i). In addition to above all-nanosheetbased flexible batteries, Hou et al. conducted successfully 2D MnCo2O4 nanosheets grown on the highly stretchable carbon cloth using hydrothermal method for flexible Li-ion batteries [92]. The binder-free MnCo2O4 nanosheets/carbon
Please cite this article in press as: B. Liu, et al., Nano Today (2
cloth composite electrodes delivered stable cycle life (over 60 times), enhanced rate capability, as well as highest areal capacity than that reported in previous literatures [93—95].

Galvanostatic ischarge/charge voltage profiles of C-LTO nanosheets, LTO anosheets, and nano-LTO electrodes with a wide range rom 1 C to 100 C were also estimated in Fig. 14e. Comared to both LTO nanosheets and nano-LTO electrodes, -LTO nanosheets electrodes showed an excellent rate per-
016), http://dx.doi.org/10.1016/j.nantod.2016.02.003
ormance and a good cycling stability due to the thin uniform arbon layer and the porous structure existed in C-LTO film, hich offers more highly conductive pathways for electrons nd fast transport channels for Li+.

hallenges and perspectives
ith the rapid development of lightweight, flexible, nd wearable electronic devices, flexible and highly fficient energy units are urgently needed. 2D nanoaterials introduced in this article include graphene aper, graphene composites, and representative inorganicaterial nanosheets. A summary regarding flexible elec-
rode based on 2D nanomaterials for Li-ion batteries can e found as well in Table 1. Although 2D nanomaterials have een widely studied for the applications in many fields such s supercapacitor, Li-ion battery, catalysis, metal-air batery, Na-ion battery [18,75—77,97—99], its application in exible energy storage devices, especially flexible Li-ion atteries is still an emerging filed. In the case of flexible attery, except for improvement of electro-chemical perormance, it is crucial to maintain the excellent stability n terms of electric, capacity, and voltage for these as-
Please cite this article in press as: B. Liu, et al., Nano Today (2
repared flexible batteries under bending. To fulfill these argets, the enhanced adhesion between active materils/flexible current collectors, improved conductivity of the hole flexible electrode as well as optimized design of 2D
anomaterials should be required as well. The main chalenges and perspectives in this filed include the following spect:
1) Most research works have focused on the preparation and characterizations of a single flexible electrode. Preparation of the complete flexible battery in a coherent approach is urgently needed. 2) More attentions should be paid to develop more efficient and scalable approach to make unique 2D nanomaterialbased electrode and a better matched flexible Li-ion batteries, especially flexible batteries based on new chemistries. 3) So far, most characterization of 2D nanomaterial-based flexible Li-ion batteries still focus on the battery level performance. Herein, more in-depth studies, including in situ characterization of charge/discharge processes of 2D nanomaterial-based flexible Li-ion batteries are
016), http://dx.doi.org/10.1016/j.nantod.2016.02.003
required to further reveal the intrinsic limitation of these batteries and their components, such as active nanomaterials, separator, and current collector under bending.

(4) It is worth noting that three dimensional (3D) integrated electrodes containing 3D conductive network support and active material served for energy storage devices have received increasing attention due to their unique electrochemical superiorities, i.e. great enhancement in effective contact area between electrolyte/active materials, high efficiency of electron/ion transport and facile diffusion of the electrolyte, and good accom-
modation of strain induced by the volume change during electrochemical reactions [32,100—103]. In fact, it is possible to make many functional nanosheets
deposited onto suitable conductive substrates with three-dimensional structure via in situ growth or various coating methods to maximize functions of both nanosheets with unique characters, and 3D freestanding films. 5) Considering emerging serious battery safety concerns, the battery-research mainstream is going back to intrinsic safety issue. Thus, some recent progresses in the
all solid-state battery systems, water-phase electrolyte, and solid ion conductors are being gradually disclosed. To smoothly incorporate these aforementioned
for flexible lithium-ion batteries.

Dr. Bin Liu is currently a research associate at Pacific Northwest National Laboratory (PNNL), Department of Energy (DOE), USA. He received his Ph.D. degree from Huazhong University of Science and Technology (HUST) in 2014. His research interest includes design and fabrication of new-generation energy storage devices made of functional nano/micromaterialsbased three-dimensional electrodes, such as flexible/wearable Li-ion batteries,
icro-supercapacitors, promising rechargeable Li-O2 batteries,
Please cite this article in press as: B. Liu, et al., Nano Today (2
lternative Mg-ion batteries, etc., as well as research on higherformance photocatalysis, photodetectors, and gas sensors based n semiconductor materials. He has published more than 40 papers n peer-reviewed journals, and holds 3 patents.
H e i i
PRESS B. Liu et al.
Dr. Ji-Guang (Jason) Zhang is a Laboratory Fellow at the Energy and Environment Directorate of the Pacific Northwest National Laboratory (PNNL) located in Richland, Washington. Currently, he is the group leader for PNNL’s efforts in the area of energy storage for mobile applications. He has 25-year experience in the development of energy storage and energy efficient devices, including lithium-ion batteries, lithium-air batteries, Lithium-metal batteries, Li-S bat-
eries, thin-film solid-state batteries, and electrochromic devices. rior to joining PNNL in June 2007, Dr. Zhang served for seven ears as Chief Technology Officer of Excellatron Solid State LLC in tlanta, Georgia. From 1998 to 2000, he served as the Director of roduct Development at Macro Energy-Tech, Inc. in Redondo Beach, alifornia. From 1990 to 1998, he was a Postdoctoral Fellow/Staff cientist/Senior Scientist at the National Renewable Energy Laboraory. Dr. Zhang holds 17 patents (with another 19 patents pending) nd publishes more than 190 papers in refereed professional jourals. He was the co-recipient of two R&D 100 awards. Dr. Zhang eceived his Ph.D. in Experimental Condensed Matter Physics from he University of Kentucky in 1990.
Prof. Guozhen Shen received his BS degree in 1999 from Anhui Normal University and Ph.D. degree in 2003 from University of Science and Technology of China. From 2004 to 2009, he conducted his research in Hanyang University (Korea), National Institute for Materials Science (Japan), University of Southern California (USA) and Huazhong University of Science and Technology. He joined Institute of Semiconductors, Chinese Academy of Sciences as a Professor in 2013.
016), http://dx.doi.org/10.1016/j.nantod.2016.02.003
is current research focuses on flexible electronics and printable lectronics, including transistors, photodetectors, sensors and flexble energy-storage devices. He has published more than 170 papers n refereed professional journals with a publication H-factor of 49.
